weeks.title: Introduction to the Book of Isaiah

images.title: Great Isaiah Scroll
images.description: High-resolution photograph of the Great Isaiah Scroll (1QIsa^a) from Qumran, showing preserved Hebrew text of Isaiah.
images.importance: This oldest complete copy of Isaiah (c. 125 BC) demonstrates textual reliability, connecting ancient scribal practices to the Dead Sea Scrolls' preservation of the prophet’s words.

images.title: Assyrian Empire Map 671 BC
images.description: Map of the Assyrian Empire at its peak under Esarhaddon (671 BC), showing Judah, Babylon, and Egypt.
images.importance: It illustrates the Assyrian dominance during Isaiah’s ministry (740–680 BC), highlighting the geopolitical threats that shaped his prophecies.

images.title: Hezekiah’s Seal
images.description: Photograph of a bulla (seal impression) of King Hezekiah, inscribed with his name in ancient Hebrew script, from 8th-century BC Judah.
images.importance: This artifact confirms Hezekiah’s reign, a key figure in Isaiah’s context, grounding the historical setting of Judah’s kings during Assyrian aggression.

images.title: Siloam Inscription
images.description: Photograph of the Siloam Inscription, a 8th-century BC Hebrew text detailing Hezekiah’s tunnel in Jerusalem.
images.importance: This inscription provides archaeological evidence of Judah’s infrastructure under Hezekiah, reflecting the historical context of Isaiah’s prophecies.

images.title: Model of Solomon’s Temple
images.description: A reconstructed model of Solomon’s Temple in Jerusalem, representing the 8th-century BC temple setting.
images.importance: This visualizes the temple where Isaiah’s throne-room vision (ch. 6) occurred, reflecting ancient Judean worship practices during Uzziah’s reign.

images.title: Map of Judah Under Uzziah
images.description: Map of Judah’s borders under Uzziah (c. 790–739 BC), showing Jerusalem and neighboring regions.
images.importance: It shows Judah’s extent during Uzziah’s reign, contextualizing the rebellion and idolatry Isaiah indicted in chapters 1-5.

images.title: Assyrian Siege Ramp
images.description: Reconstruction of an Assyrian siege ramp, used in attacks on Judean cities like Lachish.
images.importance: This illustrates Assyrian military tactics in the 8th century BC, highlighting the threats Judah faced during Isaiah’s early prophecies.

images.title: Ancient Hebrew Altar
images.description: Image of an ancient Israelite altar, used for sacrifices in Judah’s temple worship.
images.importance: It depicts the religious practices criticized by Isaiah (ch. 1) for hypocrisy, grounding the context of Judah’s spiritual decay.

images.title: Syro-Ephraimite War Map
images.description: Map illustrating the Syro-Ephraimite War (734-732 BC), showing Israel and Syria’s alliance against Judah.
images.importance: It maps the coalition against Ahaz in Isaiah 7, highlighting the geopolitical crisis that prompted the Immanuel prophecy.

images.title: Assyrian Relief of Tiglath-Pileser III
images.description: Relief showing Tiglath-Pileser III, the Assyrian king who pressured Judah during Ahaz’s reign.
images.importance: This artifact illustrates the Assyrian power Ahaz allied with (Isaiah 7-8), showing the military might Isaiah urged Judah to reject.

images.title: Davidic Throne Relief
images.description: Ancient Near Eastern relief of a king on a throne, symbolizing the Davidic line in Isaiah 9:6-7.
images.importance: It reflects the royal imagery of the Messianic king in Isaiah 11, connecting to ancient Judean expectations of a just ruler.

images.title: Hebrew Inscription of Ahaz
images.description: Bulla with ancient Hebrew inscription linked to King Ahaz, from 8th-century BC Judah.
images.importance: This artifact confirms Ahaz’s historical role, grounding the context of his faithlessness and Isaiah’s call to trust God.

images.title: Babylonian Ziggurat Reconstruction
images.description: Reconstruction of a Babylonian ziggurat, symbolizing the religious hubris of Babylon in Isaiah 13-14.
images.importance: This depicts Babylonian architecture, illustrating the empire’s pride that Isaiah prophesied against.

images.title: Moabite Stone (Mesha Stele)
images.description: Photograph of the Mesha Stele, a 9th-century BC Moabite inscription mentioning conflicts with Israel.
images.importance: It provides archaeological context for Moab in Isaiah 15-16, showing regional conflicts with Judah’s neighbors.

images.title: Philistine Pottery
images.description: Image of Philistine pottery from the 8th century BC, found in excavations near Judah.
images.importance: This artifact reflects Philistia’s culture in Isaiah 14, grounding the oracle against Judah’s western neighbor.

images.title: Egyptian Wall Relief
images.description: Relief of Egyptian pharaoh from the 8th century BC, symbolizing Egypt’s role in alliances.
images.importance: It illustrates Egypt’s prominence in Isaiah 19-20, showing why Judah’s alliance with them was futile.

images.title: Tyre’s Harbor Reconstruction
images.description: Illustration of Tyre’s ancient harbor, a Phoenician trade hub in the 8th century BC.
images.importance: This depicts Tyre’s economic power in Isaiah 23, highlighting the oracle against its pride.

images.title: Edom and Judah Map
images.description: Map showing Edom and Judah territories, with the Dead Sea border, in the 8th century BC.
images.importance: It locates Edom for Isaiah 24’s cosmic judgment, symbolizing Judah’s ancient rival in the ‘little apocalypse’.

images.title: Mount Zion View
images.description: 19th-century colored illustration of Mount Zion, Jerusalem, evoking the banquet site in Isaiah 25.
images.importance: This depicts Jerusalem’s sacred hill, central to the Messianic feast vision in Isaiah 25.

images.title: Babylonian Lion Relief
images.description: Relief of a lion from Babylon’s Ishtar Gate, symbolizing Babylonian power.
images.importance: It illustrates Babylon’s grandeur in Isaiah 21, which Isaiah’s oracles predict will fall.

weeks.title: Isaiah 28-33 (Woes on Judah and Trust in God)

images.title: Assyrian Siege Engine
images.description: Illustration of an Assyrian siege engine used in 8th-century BC campaigns against Judah.
images.importance: This shows Assyrian military technology in Isaiah 28-31, illustrating the threats Judah faced.

images.title: Egyptian Chariot Relief
images.description: Relief of an Egyptian chariot, symbolizing Egypt’s military in Isaiah 30-31.
images.importance: It depicts Egypt’s power, which Isaiah warned Judah against relying on instead of God.

images.title: Judean Ivory Carving
images.description: 8th-century BC ivory carving from Samaria, reflecting Judean elite culture.
images.importance: This artifact shows the luxury of Judah’s corrupt leaders in Isaiah 28, criticized for their drunkenness.

images.title: Sennacherib’s Campaign Map
images.description: Map of Sennacherib’s campaign routes into Judah c. 701 BC, distinct from earlier maps.
images.importance: It illustrates the specific 701 BC invasion threats in Isaiah 28-33, grounding the woes against alliances.

weeks.title: Isaiah 34-39 (Judgment, Hezekiah’s Crisis, and Exile Foreshadowed)

images.title: Lachish Relief Sennacherib
images.description: Assyrian relief panel showing the siege of Lachish with warriors and ramps, 701 BC.
images.importance: It depicts the 701 BC siege in Isaiah 36-37, providing archaeological evidence of Assyrian tactics against Judah.

images.title: Hezekiah’s Tunnel
images.description: Photograph of the interior of Hezekiah’s tunnel in Jerusalem, built to secure water during the siege.
images.importance: This shows Judah’s defensive preparations in Isaiah 36-37, reflecting Hezekiah’s practical faith.

images.title: Babylonian Chronicle Tablet
images.description: Cuneiform tablet detailing Babylonian conquests, foreshadowing exile in Isaiah 39.
images.importance: It illustrates Babylonian power, which Isaiah 39 predicts will lead to Judah’s exile.

images.title: Edomite Pottery
images.description: Image of 8th-century BC Edomite pottery, representing Edom’s culture in Isaiah 34.
images.importance: This artifact grounds the judgment on Edom, symbolizing cosmic destruction in Isaiah 34.

images.title: Babylonian Exile Map
images.description: Map showing Judah to Babylon exile routes and Persian expansion under Cyrus, c. 586-539 BC.
images.importance: It illustrates the exile context for Isaiah 40’s message of comfort, showing the path to restoration.

images.title: Cyrus Cylinder
images.description: Photograph of the Cyrus Cylinder, a 6th-century BC artifact detailing Cyrus’ conquests and decrees.
images.importance: This artifact confirms Cyrus’ role in Isaiah 45, illustrating Persian sovereignty over Judah’s return.

images.title: Babylonian Idol Statue
images.description: Image of a Babylonian deity statue, representing idol worship in Isaiah 44.
images.importance: It depicts the futility of idols Isaiah contrasts with God’s power in the exile context.

images.title: Persian Relief of Cyrus
images.description: Relief of a Persian king, possibly Cyrus, from Pasargadae, 6th century BC.
images.importance: This illustrates Cyrus’ authority in Isaiah 45, grounding God’s use of a pagan ruler.

images.title: Persian Empire Map 500 BC
images.description: Map of the Achaemenid Empire under Cyrus and successors, including Judah, c. 500 BC.
images.importance: It shows the Persian context of Isaiah 48, illustrating the empire that ended Judah’s exile.

images.title: Babylonian Processional Street
images.description: Reconstruction of Babylon’s processional street, symbolizing its grandeur in Isaiah 46-47.
images.importance: This depicts Babylon’s splendor, which Isaiah predicts will fall, contrasting with God’s power.

images.title: Persian Seal with Servant Imagery
images.description: Persian seal with a figure in service, evoking the Servant’s role in Isaiah 49-52.
images.importance: It reflects ancient imagery of servitude, connecting to the Servant’s mission to nations.

images.title: Exile Return Illustration
images.description: Illustration of Jews returning from Babylon, symbolizing Isaiah 48’s restoration.
images.importance: This visualizes the end of exile, grounding Isaiah’s promises of redemption.

images.title: Ancient Israelite Sacrifice
images.description: Illustration of an Israelite sacrificial altar, evoking the atonement imagery of Isaiah 53.
images.importance: This depicts the sacrificial system underlying the Suffering Servant’s atonement in Isaiah 53.

images.title: Post-Exilic Judah Map
images.description: Map of Judah after the return from exile, c. 539 BC, under Persian rule.
images.importance: It shows restored Judah in Isaiah 55’s covenant context, highlighting post-exile boundaries.

images.title: Covenant Renewal Tablet
images.description: Ancient Near Eastern tablet with covenant text, symbolizing Isaiah 55’s new covenant.
images.importance: This reflects ancient covenant practices, connecting to Isaiah 55’s promise of eternal mercy.

images.title: Persian Burial Relief
images.description: Relief of a Persian tomb, evoking the Servant’s burial in Isaiah 53:9.
images.importance: It illustrates ancient burial customs, grounding the Servant’s humble grave imagery.

images.title: Rebuilt Jerusalem Wall
images.description: Illustration of Jerusalem’s rebuilt walls under Nehemiah, c. 5th century BC.
images.importance: This depicts post-exilic Judah in Isaiah 56-59, showing the restored city where ethical living was emphasized.

images.title: Persian Yehud Coin
images.description: Coin from the Persian province of Yehud, 5th century BC, with Hebrew script.
images.importance: This artifact reflects Judah’s post-exilic economy in Isaiah 56, grounding the context of renewal.

images.title: Temple Menorah Relief
images.description: Relief of a menorah from the Second Temple period, symbolizing worship in Isaiah 56.
images.importance: It illustrates the inclusive worship of foreigners in Isaiah 56, connecting to temple practices.

images.title: Anointed Prophet Illustration
images.description: Illustration of an anointed prophet, evoking Isaiah 61’s messenger.
images.importance: This depicts the anointing imagery in Isaiah 61, reflecting ancient prophetic roles.

images.title: Persian Jerusalem Map
images.description: Map of Jerusalem in the Persian period, showing restored city and temple, c. 5th century BC.
images.importance: It depicts restored Jerusalem in Isaiah 62, grounding the vision of Zion’s glory.

images.title: Eschatological Vision Illustration
images.description: Illustration of a renewed creation, symbolizing Isaiah 65-66’s new heavens and earth.
images.importance: This visualizes the eschatological hope of Isaiah 65-66, reflecting ancient apocalyptic imagery.

images.title: Edomite Fortress
images.description: Photograph of an Edomite fortress ruin, representing Edom in Isaiah 63.
images.importance: This illustrates Edom’s strength, targeted for judgment in Isaiah 63’s vengeance imagery.

images.title: Second Temple Reconstruction
images.description: Reconstruction of the Second Temple in Jerusalem, c. 5th century BC.
images.importance: It depicts the temple in Isaiah 66’s universal worship, grounding the final hope vision.
